description: From Middle English wakyr, from Old English wacor, waccor (“watchful, vigilant”), from Proto-Germanic *wakraz (“awake, watchful”), equivalent to wake +‎ -er. Cognate with Scots wakir (“watchful”), Dutch wakker (“awake”), German wacker (“awake, alert, capable, brave”), Swedish vacker (“wakeful, watchful, fair, comely”).

adjectives.description: waker (comparative more waker, superlative most waker)

entries.meaning: (now chiefly UK dialectal) Watchful; vigilant; alert.

description: From Middle English wakere, equivalent to wake +‎ -er. Compare West Frisian wekker (“alarm clock”, literally “waker”), Dutch wekker, German Wecker.

entries.meaning: One who wakens or arouses from sleep.
One who wakes somebody or something.
(programming) In the Rust programming language, a handle that "wakes up" a task by notifying its executor that it is ready to be run.
